com.jackmaney.factorization

Class Power<T extends Multiplicative<T> & java.lang.Comparable<T>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.jackmaney.factorization.Power<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T -
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.util.Comparator<Power<T>>

    public class Power<T extends Multiplicative<T> & java.lang.Comparable<T>>
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.util.Comparator<Power<T>>
    Author:
    Jack Maney

    Given an object o of type T that implements the Multiplicative interface, this class represents a (positive integer) power of o.

    In order for sorting within Factorization objects, it's also necessary for T to implement Comparable.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Power()
      And we have the void constructor.
      Power(T t)
      If no exponent is provided to the constructor, then a default exponent of 1 is used.
      Power(T t, int e)
      Constructor for a Power object, requiring an object t of type T and an exponent e.

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      int compare(Power<T> o1, Power<T> o2)
      Comparison of two Power objects is done lexicographically by first comparing the bases (via Comparable), and then comparing the exponents.
      T getBase() 
      int getExponent() 
      T product()
      Uses the multiply() method provided by objects of type T to multiply base times itself a total of exponent - 1 times.
      void setBase(T base) 
      void setExponent(int exponent) 
      java.lang.String toString()
      Takes the result of the toString() method of our base, tacks on a "^", and then tacks on the exponent.

        equals, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, wait, wait, wait

    • Method Detail

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Takes the result of the toString() method of our base, tacks on a "^", and then tacks on the exponent. The base is wrapped around parentheses if base instanceof MInteger.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        String

        public int compare(Power<T> o1,
          Power<T> o2)
        Comparison of two Power objects is done lexicographically by first comparing the bases (via Comparable), and then comparing the exponents.
